ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basics of playwriting. I learned how to construct compelling events and stakes for my play. I learned the importance of objects and subtext in playwriting. I was also exposed to many different types of plays.
Knowledge of the American playwriting canon, inspiration from my classes!
Basics vocabulary/methodology of playwriting, exposure to a huge amount of contemporary Anglo-American plays, general confidence in my writing ability
I learned how to read and write plays.

I enjoyed reading a variety of American and British plays and learning the essentials of conflict, dialogue, and subtext. I learned that playwriting differs dramatically from writing for the screen because of the physical limitations and considerations of the stage. I (hopefully) learned to leave plot details in the subtext rather than explaining my plot to the audience through dialogue.
I was introduced to the practice of playwriting for the first time and learned a bit about some common literary devices, as well as reading a good portion of the contemporary English theater canon.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is really interesting but it assigned a workload that often felt unreasonable. I really enjoyed the plays we got to read.

This course has a surprisingly high reading load for a creative writing class. The workshops were sometimes useful, but often circular. However, I believe the three hour class time was simply too long; I think two 1.5 hour classes a week would lead to more engagement throughout each session. A strength of this course is the opportunity to gain feedback on our writing. Another strength was that Margulies makes himself very available during office hours.

I really enjoyed the class discussions and workshopping we did, although I do think I would have benefitted from a more structured approach to teaching us how to write our plays. I think some class time spent on how to outline a longer play and exercises focusing on specific aspects of writing like dialogue, split scenes, subtext, etc. would have made the process of writing the final play feel more manageable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It's a great introductory playwriting class. Professor Margulies is a joy to learn from and he exposes you to wonderful plays from a variety of playwrights. The weekly assignments are fun and the workshop environment is so helpful.
Yes! This is my favorite class I've taken at Yale so far.

Absolutely! Professor Margulies is an incredible resource and a great mentor. He will push you to write to the best of your abilities. That being said, you very much get out of this course what you put into it. If you don't go to office hours consistently and work on your play on your own time, your experience will be greatly diminished. Given the amount of reading and writing which this course necessitates, I caution against taking this course in a five-credit semester.

I would recommend this class to another student. You'll get to read a lot great plays and Professor Margulies is really good at teaching them. The class is a fair bit of work but if you're up for that definitely do it.

I would recommend this class to a first time playwright hoping to gain exposure to dramatic writing. Truthfully, I did not find the workshops that useful and found them occasionally frustratingly repetitive or too gentle. I also felt that Margulies allowed the class to offer far more feedback than he himself offered.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone with an interest in playwriting. I came in with no playwriting experience except a desire to learn, and I found it to be a great environment to explore in and a pretty strong introductory course, although it did at times feel slightly more catered towards students with considerable creative writing experience. The workload can be a bit heavy though, especially when you have a writing exercise or play pages due on the same day as several play readings.
